channel.title: StockHedges
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from StockHedges, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Intel shares jump 7% on earnings beat, uplifting guidance
item.description: Intel reported better-than-expected earnings following a quarter filled with challenges.

item.title: Sterling Stabilizes After Post-Budget Falls
item.description: Sterling stabilized after its post-Budget slide to a two-and-half month low against the dollar, but Ebury said “markets are clearly concerned that Lab...

item.title: Amazon Keeps Profit Margins in Orbit
item.description: The e-commerce giant’s strong operating earnings are offsetting a huge jump in AI spending and countering worries of declining margins.

item.title: Samsung Electronics' chip profit shrinks 40% from the previous quarter
item.description: The semiconductor unit reported third-quarter operating profit of 3.86 trillion won (about $2.8 billion), down 40% from the previous quarter.

item.title: Amazon shares pop on earnings beat, cloud growth
item.description: The company's cloud and advertising units showed strong growth.

item.title: You Bought Blockbuster I Bonds. Here's What to Do With Them Now.
item.description: The interest rate on new I bonds fell to about 3% as of Nov. 1.

item.title: Amazon crushed it in e-commerce and cloud, forecast an impressive holiday quarter
item.description: We're reiterating our 1 rating and raising our price target to $240 price target from $220.

item.title: Base Metals Broadly Stable With U.S. Election in Focus
item.description: Base metals were broadly stable in early European trade as a lack of strong directional appetite have kept prices supported within this week’s range, ...

item.title: Apple stuck it to the naysayers with better-than-feared financials, emerging iPhone 16 demand
item.description: While maintaining our wait-for-a-pullback 2 rating for the time being, we're increasing our price target to $250 per share from $240.

item.title: Credit and Debit Cards Ate Cash. So What's Eating Cards?
item.description: Card payments in the U.S. are no longer growing twice as fast as personal consumption: What that means for the business of plastic
